answers.answer: It sounds like you are being held in a hypothyroid state rather than at your optimal hormone levels.If you have never been tested for antibodies the doctors have been lax in diagnosing you. If they failed there, they may not be very good at reading thyroid test results, either.The lab ranges for hormone tests are very broad, and so is the range for TSH. "normal" or "within limits" does not mean healthy.If you have copies of your tests, you could post the results and the lab limits. If you haven't been in the habit of getting copies of your tests, you might consider getting a copy in the future.Welcome to the forum.

question: I have had problems with my thyroid for more than 10 years.  I was first diagnosed with an enlarged thyroid in 1995.  Thyroid levels were slightly on the hypo side.  Endo found a number of nodules and performed FNA biopsy.  Results were inconclusive.  Due to difficulty swallowing, my dr. removed part of my thyroid.  Pathology was normal.  I was placed on synthroid to prevent further development of nodules.  Several years later, more nodules were found.  Again, biopsy was inconclusive and surgery was recommended.  Entire left side removed.  Since then, I have had various problems that doctors have diagnosed as a variety of things:  reynaud's syndrome; diabetes (which, after 3 yrs and new doctor was ruled out); lyme disease (even though tests were negative) and now fibromyalgia (even though I don't have the trigger point pain required).  This has all been since the last surgery in 2003.  I am cold all the time (despite living in Florida), my hair has been falling out, my skin is very dry, I am exhausted all the time, have brain fog and find it hard to concentrate, joint pain, difficulty sleeping, restless legs, anemia, slightly higher than normal cholesterol levels, weight gain/inability to lose weight, no energy/muscle weakness and, oddly enough, my knees crackle when I walk or stoop, lock up and ache.Hypothyroidism seems to run in my family: my mom, two aunts and now my 20 yr old daughter was diagnosed with Hashimoto's and insulin resistance.I have been to several doctors and they all say that since my thyroid levels are within the "normal" range, it isn't my thyroid.  I wrote down everything so I wouldn't forget something and one doctor looked at the list and said "Good God, you look pretty good for having all these problems!" and then he laughed.  To me it isn't funny.  I had no problems whatsoever before my thyroid surgeries and now it is like I have been diagnosed with everything under the sun.  I get plenty of sleep and eat very healthy foods.  I do not have diabetes in my family (although my mother was falsely diagnosed as well when she was a child) to place me at risk of that.   My remaining thyroid is becoming more enlarged (I can feel it when I swallow and my husband reports frequent snoring/sleep apnea-type issues).  I do have nodules on the remaining side which have been monitored.  They are more numerous as time goes on.Could this be thyroid related?  I have never been tested for Hashimoto's like my daughter.  Could this be the cause?  I an very frustrated by all of this and would just love to have answers.  Thank you.
